bioghist.p: Charles P. Smyth received his AB and AM from Princeton and his Ph.D. from Harvard, where he studied under Theodore William Richards. He served as a First Lieutenant in the Chemical Warfare Service in World War I. In 1920 he began working as an instructor at Princeton. He made steady career progress there, and by 1938 he was Professor of Chemistry. His principal research involved properties of amalgams, refraction, dielectric constant and loss, dipole moment and molecular structure, molecular rotation in solids, and microwave absorption in liquids.

scopecontent.p: This collection is made up of Smyth's personal papers, and includes his high school reports, college and graduate diplomas and other documents, military records, various awards and letters of congratulation, notes for an autobiography, correspondence with T.W. Richards, and miscellaneous newspaper clippings. Also included is a set of maps and lithographs of the Adirondack region that belonged to Smyth's father, Charles H. Smyth, Jr.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
